awd_titl_txt: CAREER: "Adapt, Learn, Collaborate" — Closing the Pervasive Edge AI Loop with Liquid Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
With the maturity of massive edge computing technologies, people are increasingly looking forward to the edge deployment of artificial intelligence (AI) and hope to realize a “pervasive edge AI” ecosystem that could provide timely AI services from various edge devices and perform edge learning for sustainable service customization. However, given the vast heterogeneity in edge devices, a series of challenges also emerge: (1) How to efficiently generate adaptive AI models to accommodate vast edge system heterogeneity? (2) How to overcome the AI model heterogeneity across edge learning collaboration at the same time? (3) How to unify heterogeneous edge computing systems and provide scalable edge AI support? This project addresses these fundamental challenges with three major research thrusts: Thrust 1 thoroughly investigates the hardware resource consumption of different deep neural network (DNN) operator structures and designs a novel neural architecture search (NAS) method to address the edge heterogeneity down to the architecture level. It significantly improves the effectiveness and efficiency of edge AI model generation and adaptation. Thrust 2 advances the federated learning technique’s capability with heterogeneous AI models, by revealing the underlying structure-information correlation problem. And therefore, it enables extreme heterogeneous edge collaboration with optimal convergence and communication performance. Thrust 3 renovates the full-stack edge AI system support with hardware abstraction and software virtualization to enhance the system scalability and ease of development for pervasive edge AI development.

With these thrusts completed, this project could achieve a joint innovation with deep learning, computing system, edge collaboration techniques, and related edge AI applications. Regarding its significant advantages of flexibility and feasibility, we name this framework as “Liquid Intelligence”. With the success of this project, a pervasive and continuous edge AI ecosystem could be targeted, boosting the next wave of AI applications, edge computing, as well as other technologies. It will also contribute to many societal challenges, such as smart cities, healthcare informatics, industrial infrastructures, etc. The education plan enhances existing curricula and pedagogy by integrating interdisciplinary modules on embedded systems, mobile computing, and machine learning with newly developed teaching practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With the maturity of massive edge computing technologies, people are increasingly looking forward to the edge deployment of artificial intelligence (AI), and hope to realize a pervasive edge AI ecosystem that can provide timely AI services from various edge devices and perform edge learning for sustainable service adaptation. Given the wide heterogeneity of edge devices, a critical challenge is to efficiently and effectively generate edge-specific AI models for optimal computational performance. And an obvious technology trend is automatic methods (e.g., AutoML, NAS) that design AI model structures for specific system resources as much as possible. However, even if specific edge models can be obtained to satisfy edge resource budgets in general (e.g., in FLOPs), current NAS methods still cannot fully accommodate the edge heterogeneity of the underlying computing architectures. Moreover, accommodating edge heterogeneity in the deployment phase increases the design conflict for edge learning collaboration based on uniform model sharing and exacerbates system execution complexity. Therefore, the main goal of this project is to address three major challenges in the design of edge AI systems: (1) How to efficiently generate adaptive AI models to accommodate the vast heterogeneity of the edge? (2) How to overcome AI model heterogeneity through edge learning collaboration at the same time? (3) How to unify heterogeneous edge computing systems and provide scalable edge AI support? To address these challenges, a set of techniques are proposed and integrated into a comprehensive edge AI development and deployment framework. Such a framework can well address the adaptation, learning, and collaboration issues of heterogeneous edge devices with optimal hardware adaptability, algorithm configurability, network collaboration elasticity, and system uniformity. Given its significant advantages of flexibility and feasibility, we refer to this framework as Liquid Intelligence.

This project provides valuable resources for the artificial intelligence and mobile computing systems and have been published in many top-notch journals, including IEEE Transactions on Computers, IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design, IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, IEEE Internet of Things Journal, the Journal of Machine Learning Research, as well as top conferences in AI and EDA societies, such as KDD, ICML, ECCV, DAC, ICCAD, MLSys, WWW, ICC, ICCASP.The outcomes of this project will lead to technical innovations that tackle several major challenges of the state-of-the-art mobile and distributed system to integrate with seamless and customized AI deployment and collaboration. The proposed technical innovations represent a significant leap forward in AI design and deployment methodology, emphasizing edge-oriented design space construction, heterogeneous federated learning, and edge AI system virtualization and unification. This integrated framework promises to revolutionize edge AI design and deployment cycles, streamline the virtualization of edge AI services, and enhance accessibility for developers and edge users alike. Upon successful implementation, this project has the potential to establish a ubiquitous and continuous edge AI ecosystem, catalyzing the development of the next wave of AI applications, edge computing, and related technologies. Building on our current progress, we have initiated early explorations into applying our edge AI adaptation and collaboration techniques to large-scale edge applications. Moving forward, we remain committed to exploring emerging applications and trends, ensuring our research remains at the forefront of innovation.

From the education perspective, at George Mason University, research training opportunities were offered to three PhD students and one postdoc researcher. The PI work closely with these trainees and mentored them jointly. The project also offers research opportunities to an undergraduate student, who published his first conference paper on a topic at the intersection of information theory and multi-user private information retrieval. The PI also offered research relevant courses, such as Intelligent Computing Systems, Distributed and Federated Learning Systems, , etc., as well as weekly seminars to both undergraduate and graduate students. Several PhD students are involved in this project as well. The project activities help them better understand the principles of intelligent computer engineering and find their research directions. It is worth mentioning that some PhD students who were partially supported by this project have finished their dissertations and become tenure-track professors right after their graduation.
